pull.title: scripts: add PE dylib checking to symbol-check.py
pull.body:
Uses `objdump -x` and looks for `DLL Name:` lines. i.e:
```bash
objdump -x src/qt/bitcoin-qt.exe | grep "DLL Name:"
	DLL Name: ADVAPI32.dll
	DLL Name: dwmapi.dll
	DLL Name: GDI32.dll
	DLL Name: IMM32.dll
	DLL Name: IPHLPAPI.DLL
	DLL Name: KERNEL32.dll
	DLL Name: msvcrt.dll
	DLL Name: ole32.dll
	DLL Name: OLEAUT32.dll
	DLL Name: SHELL32.dll
	DLL Name: SHLWAPI.dll
	DLL Name: USER32.dll
	DLL Name: UxTheme.dll
	DLL Name: VERSION.dll
	DLL Name: WINMM.dll
	DLL Name: WS2_32.dll
```

events.body:
Concept ACK

Capitalization is not significiant in this context, right? If so I suggest `.lower()`:ing all DLL names to make the script less fragile.

Concept ACK 20916eaea294fb62c2a5b4e466aa89c57cfcba21

Does [contrib/devtools/README.md - symbol-check.py](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/master/contrib/devtools#symbol-checkpy) need update to mention Windows OS?

Concept ACK (left one nit code review comment)
I support practicalswift's suggestion to not check for the DLL names in case-sensitive manner.
The capitalization is fixed and determined by our build process, I don't think it's a problem to check case sensitively.

verification.payload:
tree c3463a77051878457fcb7e7f3c38532683c070ef
parent 5504703a9f8388dff66d33bd077bcc4c82dff6c8
author fanquake <fanquake@gmail.com> 1584771782 +0800
committer fanquake <fanquake@gmail.com> 1584845258 +0800

scripts: add PE dylib checking to symbol-check.py

events.message: scripts: add PE dylib checking to symbol-check.py

events.body:
> Does contrib/devtools/README.md - symbol-check.py need update to mention Windows OS?

Done.

> Capitalization is not significiant in this context, right? If so I suggest .lower():ing all DLL names to make the script less fragile.

> I support practicalswift's suggestion to not check for the DLL names in case-sensitive manner.

@practicalswift @theStack Can you clarify what the benefits of lower-casing would be? 

From what I can tell that would just introduce the ability for changes in the build to be unnecessarily hidden. i.e we could end up linked against `a.dll` and `A.dll` DLLs and that would go unnoticed.

I care far less about this script being fragile than I care about knowing what is happening in our gitian build. If for some reason a bunch of DLLs get renamed it's probably something we want to know about.

> The capitalization is fixed and determined by our build process, I don't think it's a problem to check 
case sensitively.

Though I never went through the process of building Bitcoin Core for Windows, I was assuming that it is far from clear if the capitalization is really _always_ fixed (as it doesn't need to be for the resulting binary to work), but possibly rather dependent on the concrete build environment (OS/Toolchain, maybe even used file system?). My admittedly hasty rationale was that this script could outside of gitian builds may also be useful for people to validate inofficial binaries.

> I care far less about this script being fragile than I care about knowing what is happening in our gitian build. If for some reason a bunch of DLLs get renamed it's probably something we want to know about.

Yes, for gitian builds, that absolutely makes sense, better err on the side of caution.

ACK 1a0993ae354c36d6f219e67f82ca8236530d6201, tested on Linux Mint 19.3:
```
$ make -C depends HOST=x86_64-w64-mingw32
$ CONFIG_SITE=$PWD/depends/x86_64-w64-mingw32/share/config.site ./configure
$ make
$ make -C src check-symbols
make: Entering directory '/home/hebasto/GitHub/bitcoin/src'
make[1]: Entering directory '/home/hebasto/GitHub/bitcoin'
make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/hebasto/GitHub/bitcoin'
Checking Windows dynamic libraries...
make: Leaving directory '/home/hebasto/GitHub/bitcoin/src'
```

Verified that DLLs were retrieved from binaries by `/usr/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-objdump` which belongs to the [`binutils-mingw-w64-x86-64`](https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/binutils-mingw-w64-x86-64) package. This package is installed on gitian as a dependency of [`gcc-mingw-w64-x86-64`](https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/gcc-mingw-w64-x86-64) which, in turn, is a dependency of https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/5504703a9f8388dff66d33bd077bcc4c82dff6c8/contrib/gitian-descriptors/gitian-win.yml#L20

issue.title: guix: Enable building for `x86_64-w64-mingw32` target
issue.body:
~~Based on: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/16519~~
Based on: #17933 (Time Machines are... shall we say... superior :grin:)

This PR allows us to perform Guix builds for the `x86_64-w64-mingw32` target. We do this _without_ splitting up the build script like we do in Gitian by using this newfangled alien technology called `case` statements. (This is WIP and might be changed to `if` statements soon)

issue.title: Bugfix: devtools/symbol-check: Check PE libraries case-insensitively
issue.body:
For some reason, one of my gitian builds failed because "DLL" was uppercase where `symbol-check.py` expected it lowercase.

Since the PE platform is case insensitive, check it case-insensitively here too.

issue.title: Bitcoin PR tracking
issue.body: The main purpose of this issue is to keep track of Pull Requests on Bitcoin since version 0.19.1 identifying those which make a porting LitecoinZ.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -218,6 +239,26 @@ def check_MACHO_libraries(filename) -> bool:
             ok = False
     return ok
 
+def pe_read_libraries(filename) -> List[str]:
+    p = subprocess.Popen([OBJDUMP_CMD, '-x', filename], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, stdin=subprocess.PIPE, universal_newlines=True)
+    (stdout, stderr) = p.communicate()
+    if p.returncode:
+        raise IOError('Error opening file')
+    libraries = []
+    for line in stdout.splitlines():
+        if 'DLL Name:' in line:
+            tokens = line.split()
+            libraries.append(tokens[2])
comments.body:
nit: wouldn't rely on the whitespace in the left-hand side description string here, but rather use ': ' as seperator and then access with index 1.
```suggestion
            tokens = line.split(': ')
            libraries.append(tokens[1])
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -218,6 +239,26 @@ def check_MACHO_libraries(filename) -> bool:
             ok = False
     return ok
 
+def pe_read_libraries(filename) -> List[str]:
+    p = subprocess.Popen([OBJDUMP_CMD, '-x', filename], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, stdin=subprocess.PIPE, universal_newlines=True)
+    (stdout, stderr) = p.communicate()
+    if p.returncode:
+        raise IOError('Error opening file')
+    libraries = []
+    for line in stdout.splitlines():
+        if 'DLL Name:' in line:
+            tokens = line.split()
+            libraries.append(tokens[2])
